RT @TheStalwart: .@surajpatelnyc makes the case for Joe Manchin‚Äôs vision of energy permitting reform https://t.co/AGMDTFGlbq https://t.co/m‚Ä¶

32/ Reforming the permitting process to make it easier to fight global warming is a moral obligation, even if it means letting a fossil fuel project go forward like the one Mr. Manchin wants in West Virginia.
31/ The @IFP has outlined a list of policy suggestions to prevent NEPA from being used to harm the environment. https://t.co/0FtqhUmKSQ
30/ Unbelievably, carbon-free geothermal projects do not get the same treatment, they must file NEPA reports essentially dooming them against their dirtier competitors.

29/ Specifically, The 2005 Energy Policy Act created a loophole for oil and gas exploration on federal land exempting many oil and gas projects across the Western United States from having to comply with NEPA.

28/ Fossil fuels development is categorically exempt from many NEPA reviews & older incumbents have had decades to work the process; 42% of the DOE's active NEPA reviews are related to clean energy, transmission or conservation; only 15% are related to fossil fuels.

27/ Instead, the vast majority of litigants were special interest groups, sometimes from shell organizations funded by fossil fuel interests.

The irony is NEPA actually hampers renewable energy much more than fossil fuels and highway repaving.
26/ True, it allows any citizen to bring a lawsuit to halt a project, but a recent study found that only 3 percent of NEPA litigants were Native American tribes or local residents.

25/ Opponents of red tape reform will point out that more community input is critical, which was the original purpose of NEPA. But today, the reality is that NEPA has become a tool of regulatory capture.

24/ One important recent quantitative analysis of NEPA from Trevor Salter of the University of California, Davis, argues that current law advances land preservation interests too far at the expense of renewable energy project development. https://t.co/WPy1XpK3ZW
23/ Today our challenges are global, but the manner in which NEPA is commonly interpreted and applied can favor the status quo and disfavor developing land for renewable energy projects.
22/ NEPA was passed in the 1970s, when localized environmental damage like toxic waste was the key concern.

21/ Properly reforming NEPA is a generational question. Right now we have process-based environmental protections with mixed results. Reform would reimagine a substance-based environmental protection regime that takes the entire planet into consideration.

20/ Even forest fire prevention suffers: Congress recently tried to pass a specific
NEPA carve out in the Save Our Sequoias Act because the Forest Service‚Äôs wildfire prevention projects are delayed an average of 3.5 to 7.2 years.

19/ California‚Äôs high-speed rail system has been delayed for nearly a decade because of lengthy procedural delays. The federal government cannot even put solar panels on its roofs without triggering a NEPA review.

18/ Mass transit authorities have great difficulty getting projects approved in a timely manner. It‚Äôs partially why New York‚Äôs Second Avenue subway was delayed; it‚Äôs next three phases will each require a separate review.

17/ Another Cape Cod wind farm was canceled after 16 years of NEPA delays and hundreds of millions spent in sunk costs; and it took 11 years of NEPA delays before a big wind project in Wyoming was finally approved.

16/ NEPA reviews also frequently kill wind projects: In one, wind farms off the coast of Martha‚Äôs Vineyard ‚Äî which would produce enough to power approximately 720,000 homes with clean energy ‚Äî were delayed for years.
15/ Bike lanes in San Francisco were delayed by a report that reached 1,353 pages, 2.5 years, and over $1 million in costs because of the NEPA review.
14/ For example, New York‚Äôs congestion pricing was delayed by NEPA and pushed to 2023 despite passing in 2019 because of the consideration of numerous ‚Äúalternative routes‚Äù to avoid litigation.

13/ NEPA has recently claimed a number of clean energy projects. Here's a great thread of examples; 
https://t.co/tiKxKl1azz
12/ They are routinely thousands of pages and take years to complete, and more often than not, they‚Äôre used to kill projects with a slow death or make them exorbitantly expensive.
11/ .@ENERGY reported that the average completion time for an environmental-impact statement in 2015 was 4.1 years, and the average cost was $4.2 million.
10/ In the beginning, these statements were routinely about 10 pages long. Today, what was born as a good idea has turned into a demon.
9/ NEPA requires all construction projects under federal jurisdiction to conduct an environmental-impact statement on a given project.

8/ Our environmental regulatory regime is largely focused on process, rather than substantive outcomes. No law on the book exemplifies that more than the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (known as NEPA).

7/ To build support for a lasting environmental movement, we need to decouple environmentalism from a perceived drop in standard of living. Speeding the way for an environmental agenda focused rapidly creating an abundance of clean energy accomplishes just that.

6/ In the United States, a long history of perceived sacrifice to achieve environmental goals has led to a belief that economic growth and the environment are locked in a zero-sum game, that growth suffers from decarbonization.
5/ .@POTUS's commitment to getting cranes in the sky and shovels in the ground to transform our economy to carbon neutrality hangs in the balance.
4/ To rapidly decarbonize, we need to build wind, solar, geothermal, nuclear, power lines, and lithium mines fast; The only way to do that is to streamline the regulatory process.
3/ We have become a ‚Äúvetocracy‚Äù and Red tape in permitting functions has become another veto point because regulatory regimes inevitably get captured by special interests.

2/ The power to veto is an intoxicating strain in American politics. Our system from Senate's composition, the Filibuster, gerrymandering at all levels, NIMBY referendums, commissions, and interest group litigation gives power to a vocal minority that hampers progress.

1/ If we want to meet our 2050 zero carbon goal, red tape reform is not an option. It is vital. That's why I wrote that Democrats need to embrace it and put renewables on an even footing with fossil fuels in @TIME

1) It's act‚Ä¶

34/ The world depends on American ingenuity and creativity. Other countries (including China) are aggressively investing in research and development to dominate the technology fields of the future. Decline is a policy choice. We need to keep up. We need to lead the future.

33/ Technological progress is a social justice issue. Pivotal breakthroughs and advances in science and technology can have the most meaningful impact on the lives of disadvantaged people and those of limited means.
32/ Congress would then give an up or down vote on the Commission‚Äôs recommendations.

31/ The Commission‚Äôs mandate should encompass both targeting regulations that hold back innovative projects, and those that impose excessive ‚Äútime taxes‚Äù on individuals trying to access government programs, especially the burdens imposed by tax returns that are not auto-filled.
30/ The RIC would identify regulations that should either be eliminated or modified in order to streamline and promote innovation.

29/ And more generally, we should take a fresh look at the broader regulatory environment to identify rules that are unduly hindering innovation and advancement. Congress should set up a Regulatory Improvement Commission modeled on the commission used for closing military bases.
28/ We can start by following the European model and splitting the FDA up into separate agencies to specialize in food and drug safety, respectively.

27/ We must also reform the Food & Drug Administration to expedite the approval process of new breakthrough medicines. As we‚Äôve learned all too well during the COVID-19 pandemic, FDA delays in approving safe and effective drugs have real and detrimental costs to people‚Äôs lives.

26/ Regulatory decision-making on new nuclear facilities should track the same kind of cost-benefit analysis we apply to environmental regulations generally: whether the environmental and energy gains outweigh any potential safety risks.
25/ We should also modernize our regulatory state to make it hospitable to new forms of zero-carbon energy sources, like next-generation nuclear reactors.
24/ To make this feasible, we should centralize permitting into as few federal offices as possible, and staff up those offices with more experts equipped to make smart permitting determinations.
23/ Environmental reviews and permitting determinations should be completed in 18 months or less so that projects can have reasonably swift certainty about whether they may move forward.
22/ We should also impose a ‚Äúshot clock‚Äù on permitting decisions by government agencies under NEPA and other laws.
21/ We should at minimum secure energy parity by giving clean energy projects like wind, solar, and geothermal equal treatment under NEPA.

20/ Right now, oil and gas are virtually exempt from NEPA ‚Äì meaning that the current statutory framework of the ‚Äúenvironmental‚Äù law is perversely stacked against clean energy development and in favor of fossil fuel extraction.
19/ Environmental reviews can drag on for years and stall important infrastructure projects in the process.
18/ Today, NEPA is too often used as a cudgel by NIMBYs to tie up offshore wind farms and other clean energy projects with lengthy lawsuits and behemoth environmental impact statements.

17/ To take one example: The National Environmental Policy Act was a well-intentioned 1960s conservationist law intended to protect nature by placing the burden on federal agencies to demonstrate that permitted infrastructure projects wouldn‚Äôt harm the environment.

16/ Secondly, we must pave the way for innovation by rethinking permitting and other regulatory obstacles. Regulations that made sense in isolation or in a past era have accumulated to create logjams of "vetocracy" that stymy progress.

15/ For mental health research, we need to double funding for the BRAIN Initiative, which is striving to map the brain in the same way we mapped the human genome in order to deepen our knowledge of brain disorders and to develop tools to treat them.

14/ Let's also spin off new ‚ÄúARPAs‚Äù focused on non-defense science and innovation in other areas of national importance. We need an ARPA for healthcare, construction technology, transportation, and agriculture and food systems.

13/ We must increase funding for the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), which has been integral in developing technologies from the Internet to GPS to mRNA vaccines as well as ARPA-E, which is focused on energy.

12/ Operation Warp Speed should be made permanent to continue supporting the far-reaching potential of mRNA vaccines ‚Äì not just for COVID-19 variants, but to expedite the day when we have vaccines to protect against cancers, malaria, and other intractable diseases.
11/ Let‚Äôs also redouble our commitment to programs proven to work in supporting key innovations.

10/ Similarly, because the government is such a large purchaser, it can strategically use its procurement policies to support promising nascent technology, such as carbon-negative concrete and other clean building materials.
9/ The federal government can issue advance market commitments to kickstart critical breakthroughs like scaled-up carbon capture by guaranteeing a market for commercialized technology.
8/ We should be utilizing the power of government spending to shape market incentives to promote technological advancement.

7/ It will also allow us to deploy our technologies at home and abroad to fight climate change and counter China‚Äôs ‚ÄúBelt and Road Initiative.‚Äù It's long overdue we harness America's economic prowess for the greater good of humanity and offer an alternative to Chinese debt traps.

16/ We must reform and expand our mental healthcare system, remove barriers to mental healthcare, and heavily fund research for promising mental health treatment. We must build a country that is committed to supporting every person‚Äôs mental well-being every step of the way.

13/ The goal is to uncover the mysteries of brain disorders from Alzheimer's to schizophrenia and to discover a new generation of tools and technologies to treat them.

17/ Congress cannot just take a back seat during this crisis and we cannot count on old thinking and old playbooks. As we‚Äôve learned time and again during the last two years, we need new ideas, new playbooks, and a new vision to see America through this moment.
16/ This delay is inexcusable during a time when Americans are reeling from broken supply chains and high inflation.

15/ This critical legislation has been in the works since 2020 and should have been passed within the first 100 days of the Biden presidency but has been held up in conference committee since as each chamber negotiates over the differences.

14/ The COMPETES Act invests billion to strengthen our supply chains, invests in domestic manufacturing of semiconductors, equips the Commerce Department with an assistant secretary to oversee supply chains, and more.

13/ The federal government should enact a subsidized employment program, particularly in sectors experiencing a labor shortage such as trucking. We should also work to streamline licensing and training for truck drivers.

12/ Congress should also authorize funding to clear backlogs in housing development and finally work to remove local zoning restrictions that are blocking the much-needed production of affordable housing.

11/ As mentioned above, suspending tariffs on key inputs that go into housing construction such as lumber, aluminum, and semi-truck chassis will help reduce price volatility that delay and increase the cost of housing production.

10/ Congress must work to reduce the price of housing and healthcare. We must start by allowing Medicare to negotiate the price of prescription drugs and by blocking the proposed 8% payment bump from Medicare to private insurers.
9/ These tariffs have contributed to the price volatility of major inputs such as Canadian lumber and aluminum which often put businesses into a bind and lead to delays during building.

8/ We must also suspend all non-Russia-related tariffs. A recent report from @PIIE found that suspending tariffs would result in a one-time reduction of 1.3 percentage points on the consumer price index, a commonly cited indicator of inflation.

7/ Next, we must suspend archaic and counter-productive statutes that make inflation worse by artificial gumming up our supply chains. The Jones Act and the Foreign Dredge Act of 1906. These laws increase costs and limit the capacity of our shipping systems and supply chain.

6/ President Biden should strike a deal to ease refinery capacity bottlenecks for short-term oil and gas production in exchange for the $500 billion in clean energy provisions to end our dependence on fossil fuels and cement our path to carbon neutrality by 2035.
5/ Demand reduction is necessary, but not sufficient.

4/ Oil and gas are inputs that go into the production of everything and are raising prices across the board. We must reduce the demand for oil and gas by incentivizing carpooling, temporarily reducing or eliminating fares for public transit, and more.

3/ Domestically this will help bolster commodity production amidst tightening financial conditions while internationally, help stabilize the global economy thus strengthening our efforts against Putin‚Äôs illegitimate war in Ukraine.

2/ Energy and food prices are key drivers of this inflation - these are mainly being pushed up by commodity shocks caused by Putin's War in Ukraine. I urge @POTUS and @SecYellen to utilize the Exchange Stabilization Fund (ESF) to ramp up and safeguard commodity production.

1/ Inflation accelerated to a staggering 9.1% - a four decade high. As I've been saying for months, if Congress and the White House don't act, the Fed will aggressively hike us into a recession. The clock is ticking - here's what we need to do:

15/ While hardened shorelines destroy the environment, living shorelines help heal the environment by increasing biodiversity, sequestering carbon, and cleaning the water.
14/ Living shorelines dissipate and absorb wave energy in addition to growing in height naturally as sea levels rise.

12/ Living shorelines are more effective at providing climate resiliency than hardened shorelines. Existing but depleted wetlands saved New York and New Jersey $625 billion in damages from flooding during Hurricane Sandy.

11/ Unlike the hardened, non-organic, and rigid landfill structure currently proposed, a living shoreline would adapt and grow over time as our city ‚Äì and our climate crisis ‚Äì evolves. As an added bonus, living shorelines sequester carbon.

Today as on Election Night, we stand with the thousands of activists, advocates, & believers in democracy working to ensure every vote is counted, every voice is heard, and New York has the representation we deserve. This is an issue of justice a& equal protection under the law.

This situation can be remedied by allowing every ballot without a postmark received by June 30th to be counted, thereby acknowledging the sound intentions of the thousands of New Yorkers who stand to be disenfranchised through no fault of their own.

Here is the inherent conflict: the law states that a postmark may be the deciding factor in the validation of a ballot, but voters were provided return envelopes that did not require postmarks through the USPS.

an energy that embodies Hamilton himself. The culminating event, of course, was President Obama‚Äôs attendance and speech that paid homage to the story of the immigrant founding father whose story was embodies the best of America and the millions who see themselves and their kids

working during the day while the cast was performing or rehearsing. @Lin_Manuel was kind enough to let me use his dressing room as our staff office and I would watch with awe and he‚Äôd dash in and out every few minutes with costume changes and an energy that only he possesses,

It is the story of a City brought to its knees, our City, and those who sacrificed everything in hopes that others would have prosperity and opportunity.

Hamilton is the story of an immigrant kid who is constantly told to wait his turn, and who feels a deep sense of urgency to make the most of the time he‚Äôs been given. Young, scrappy, and hungry, I know I‚Äôm not the only immigrant kid to see myself in his words.

In today‚Äôs political climate, Juneteenth carries new meaning. With senseless police brutality, voter suppression, and health care inequality during COVID, more than ever it‚Äôs important to reflect on Juneteenth. We must think of how far we‚Äôve come and how much more we need to do.

Juneteenth marks the day that 250,000 enslaved people were told that they were free. Sources say it was that moment when celebrations broke out. Those celebrations became the annual tradition we know as Juneteenth.
Some believe messengers were murdered on their way to inform the enslaved people, other historians believe this was due to having minimal Union soldiers in the area at this time.

A 155 year old holiday, Juneteenth is the annual remembering of the day Union Army Maj. Gen. Gordon Granger informed enslaved people in Gavelston, TX that they were free. This was two years after the Emancipation Proclamation was issued. The reasons for this delay are debated.

While Juneteenth marks the official end of slavery, we cannot forget that it took two years to emancipate enslaved people. We also cannot forget the decades to follow that continued to systematically marginalize Black folks. We cannot forget what‚Äôs going on now either.

#Juneteenth, the oldest commemoration of Emancipation in US history. Today is a time to not only remember all those who suffered under the racist institution of slavery, but to celebrate the achievements of the Black community and reflect on the work still needing to be done.

I proudly support the House resolution condemning police violence, as well as H.R.40 - which would establish a commission to study and develop policies for reparations for slavery.

Enough is enough. Black Lives Matter. We must act louder than we speak.

To close the disparities in our healthcare system we must pass Medicare for All and address the shortage of Black doctors. We must also provide more funding to Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). To close the racial wealth gap, we must pass Baby Bonds

The DOJ must investigate incidents of police brutality and violence. Departments that receive federal intervention have 25-30% fewer police shootings than those that do not. We need to invest genuine resources to fix the systemic, structural issues that harm Black communities.

We must demilitarize police departments, push for higher standards of training in de-escalation tactics, and hold officers who abuse the use of force accountable. An officer fired for violence or any form of misconduct should not be able to work for other police departments.

Sentencing disparities, selective enforcement of the law, and police brutality disproportionately harm Black Americans. We must legalize marijuana and retroactively expunge all marijuana related records.

To address the continued trauma that Black Americans face every day, we must support and actively push for the goals of the #BlackLivesMatter movement, including ending over-policing, mass incarceration, police brutality, violence against Black people, & decriminalizing poverty.
